questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought for evaluation of repeated lung infections. The bronchial fluid samples show gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a bluish-green pigment. He also has been experiencing foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools. What is the mode of inheritance of the condition that the child is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Repeated lung infections and steatorrhea (foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools) suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a blue-green pigment indicate infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is commonly seen in this condition. 

Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7 (7q31.2). It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

  • Lungs - Abnormal CFTR leads to sticky viscous mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance leading to obstruction and recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - The viscous secretions block the pancreatic ducts impairing the flow of digestive enzymes. This leads to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing fat malabsorption and the resultant steatorrhea. 
  • Reproductive tract - More than 95% of men are infertile, with absent vas deferens. Women have tenacious cervical mucus but are not always infertile. 

The sweat chloride test is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Sweat ducts with normal CFTR reabsorb the chloride from the primary sweat secretion. Mutated CFTR reduces this uptake, increasing chloride levels in sweat. A sweat chloride level of >60 mmol/L is diagnostic.

Other pathogens commonly causing infections in cystic fibrosis include Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Burkholderia cepacia.

questions.text:
You are evaluating a 39-year-old male patient for malabsorption and vitamin B12 deficiency. He undergoes a Schilling test and the findings observed are given in the table. What is the likely diagnosis?
Test Absorption
Co-labeled cobalamin Reduced
With intrinsic factor Normal
With pancreatic enzymes Reduced
With Antibiotics for 5 days Reduced
questions.solution:
Normal absorption of Vit B12 with intrinsic factor is seen in Pernicious Anemia.

Pernicious anemia can be defined as a severe lack of intrinsic factor due to gastric atrophy. People who have pernicious anemia can't absorb enough vitamin B12 from food. This is because they lack intrinsic factor, a protein made in the stomach. 

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma- Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors. In 75% of patients, gastrinomas are sporadic, solitary lesions. The remaining 25% of patients with gastrinomas have multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Gastrinomas usually arise in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Patients present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. The acidic environment impairs the function of digestive enzymes (pancreatic enzymes), leading to the malabsorption of nutrients. This malabsorption results in an osmotic gradient, drawing water into the intestinal lumen, which contributes to diarrhea. 

Treatment of individuals with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome includes blockade of acid hypersecretion, typically with proton pump inhibitors. 

Other options:

Option A: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumor.

Option C: Glucagonomas, α-cell tumors are associated with increased serum levels of glucagon. The patient presents with mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia. They occur most frequently in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women and are characterized by extremely high plasma glucagon levels.

Option D: Insulinomas, β-cell tumors are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50 mg/dL. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. A peripheral smear showed acanthocytosis. A biopsy specimen of the small intestine is shown below. Identify the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an infant presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis in the peripheral smear, and a histopathological image showing lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein which leads to the inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Thus lipids get accumulate intracellularly. It is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life. They present with failure to thrive and steatorrhea.

Deep tendon reflexes are absent due to peripheral neuropathy and peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis due to lipid membrane defects, which is secondary to marked vitamin E deficiency.

Histopathology shows normal intestinal mucosa except lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed.

Low fat, high caloric, vitamin-enriched diet, and vitamin E in large doses should be given. Inadequate supply of vitamin E results in neurological degeneration and the development of retinitis pigmentosa.

 

Diarrhea is defined as an increase in stool mass, frequency, or fluidity, typically greater than 200 gm per day. It can be classified into 4 types:

  • Secretory diarrhea is an isotonic stool and persists during fasting.
  • Osmotic diarrhea is due to the osmotic force exerted by unabsorbed luminal solutes. The diarrheal fluid is greater than 50 mOsm. Diarrhea decreases on fasting.
  • Malabsorptive diarrhea is due to failure of nutrient absorption. It is associated with steatorrhea and it gets relived on fasting.
  • Exudative diarrhea is due to inflammatory diseases which has pus and blood on them, it continues during fasting.

Other options:

Option A- Lactase deficiency is due to the absence of lactase in the villous epithelial cells. Lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and exerts an osmotic force causing osmotic diarrhea. Since the defect is biochemical, histology appears normal.

Option C- Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten-containing foods. Histology shows villous atrophy intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia. Plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils are seen in lamina propria.

Histopathology image of celiac disease is shown below:

 

Option D- Whipple's disease is a malabsorptive syndrome. Histology shows foamy macrophages in the small intestinal propria. The macrophages are laden with gram-positive, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant granules that have partially digested Tropheryma whipplei within the lysosome.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient with Crohn's disease underwent resection of a segment of the bowel. Following resection, the patient noticed that his stools have become bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and float in the toilet bowl. Which of the following statements is false regarding the resected segment of the bowel?

choices.text: It is the only site of absorption of bile salts
It is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12
Resection of this segment leads to decreased gastric motility
Oral cholestyramine may be required in resections as small as 100cm

questions.solution:
The history of bulky, pale, and floating stools indicates steatorrhea which is seen in ileal resection. Resection of the ileum does not lead to decreased gastric motility.

Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum, thus, results in a significant enhancement of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit. This results in increased delivery of fluids and electrolytes to the colon which results in symptoms of diarrhea. 

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts (Options A & B). Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption (steatorrhea). The loss of bile salts into the colon affects the colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Resections as small as 100cm can cause steatorrhoea, which requires the administration of oral cholestyramine to bind the bile salts (Option D). Larger resections may require dietary fat restriction.

questions.text: Which of the following alpha beta 7 integrin inhibitors is used in the treatment of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Vedolizumab is a humanized anti-alpha-4-beta-7 integrin monoclonal antibody that prevents lymphocyte recruitment to the intestinal mucosa and is approved for use in moderate-severe Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Anti-TNF alpha monoclonal antibodies indicated in IBD are: 

  • Infliximab
  • Adalimumab
  • Certolizumab pegol

Other options : 

Option C: Natalizumab is an anti-alpha-4-beta-7 integrin inhibitor monoclonal antibody used in treating Multiple Sclerosis, particularly in patients who are JC virus negative.

questions.text: A patient with celiac disease presents with peripheral neuropathy and decreased vibration and position sense. Investigations show hemolytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid levels. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic malabsorption due to celiac disease, and has now presented with peripheral neuropathy and posterior column involvement (loss of vibration and position sense). The presence of hemolytic anemia along with these features points to a diagnosis of vitamin E deficiency.

Vitamin E (α-tocopherol) acts as an antioxidant by scavenging free radicles. It is a fat-soluble vitamin, and so the deficiency is only seen in patients with prolonged malabsorption, such as celiac disease and chronic cholestatic liver disease. Children with abetalipoproteinemia cannot absorb vitamin E and also show symptoms of deficiency. 

Deficiency of vitamin E causes axonal degeneration of myelinated neurons, causing posterior column and spinocerebellar involvement. Patients can have peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, and loss of vibration and position sense. Along with this, there is hemolytic anemia because of unchecked lipid peroxidation of the RBC membrane in the absence of the antioxidant effects of vitamin E.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (option C) can also present with involvement of the posterior column, but the following features differentiate it from vitamin E deficiency:

  Vitamin E deficiency Vitamin B12 deficiency
Anemia Hemolytic anemia Megaloblastic anemia
Peripheral smear Acanthocytes Macroovalocytes with hypersegmented neutrophils
Serum methylmalonic acid levels Normal Elevated

Other options:

Option A: Pyridoxine deficiency presents with epithelial changes such as cheilitis, along with peripheral neuropathy, personality changes, and depression. There is no involvement of the posterior column tracts. Pyridoxine deficiency can cause microcytic hypochromic anemia due to diminished hemoglobin synthesis, since the aminolevulinate synthase enzyme in heme synthesis is PLP dependent. 

Option B: Folate deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia without neurological symptoms. There is an elevation of serum homocysteine levels but methylmalonic acid levels are normal, versus vitamin B12 deficiency, where both are elevated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gentleman presents to the clinic with bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and crampy abdominal pain for the past week. The colonoscopy image is given below. Which of the following is commonly not associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic image point to a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Urethritis is not an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosa of the colon and rectum. It presents with chronic diarrhea, tenesmus, mucus and blood passage per rectum, and crampy abdominal pain.

Sigmoidoscopy shows severe colon inflammation with erythema, friability, and exudates. Active disease is associated with a rise in acute-phase reactants (C-reactive protein), platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a decrease in hemoglobin. Diagnosis is based on the patient’s clinical symptoms, sigmoidoscopic appearance, and histology of rectal or colonic biopsy specimens.

Extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis 

  • Musculoskeletal -
    • Arthritis
    • Sacroiliitis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Eye -
    • Uveitis/Iritis
    • Episcleritis
  •  Skin -
    • Erythema nodosum
    • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Hepatobiliary -
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
    • Fatty liver
    • Cholelithiasis
  • Hematopoietic/coagulation -
    • Venous and arterial thromboembolism
  • Cardiopulmonary -
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • pleuropericarditis
    • endocarditis
    • myocarditis
  • Urologic -
    • Calculi
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Ileal bladder fistula

questions.text: An obese patient was prescribed a drug for weight loss that acts by inhibiting gastrointestinal lipase. Which among the following is the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
Orlistat is a drug indicated for weight loss and acts by inhibiting gastrointestinal lipase resulting in reduced lipid absorption.

Orlistat is a reversible gastrointestinal lipase inhibitor required for the hydrolysis of dietary fat into fatty acids and monoacylglycerols. Orlistat acts in the lumen of stomach and small intestine by forming covalent bonds with the active site of lipases. This leads to reduced digestion and absorption of dietary fat. Adverse effects include flatus with discharge, fecal urgency, fatty/oily stool, and increased defecation. These side effects are experienced early and diminish as patients control their dietary fat intake. Vitamin supplements are indicated to prevent fat soluble vitamin deficiency.

Adjuvant pharmacologic treatments for obesity should be considered for patients with a BMI ≥30 kg/m2, or for patients with a BMI ≥27 kg/m2 who have concomitant obesity-related diseases and for whom dietary and physical activity therapy has not been successful. Medications for obesity include those that affect appetite (liraglutide, phentermine)  and those that inhibit gastrointestinal fat absorption (orlistat).

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) analogue which is approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, and is used as an off label indication for weight loss. It acts as an incretin hormone (glucose-induced insulin secretion), inhibits both gastric emptying and glucagon secretion and stimulates GLP-1 receptors in the arcuate nucleus of hypothalamus to reduce feeding.

Option C: Phentermine is a sympathomimetic central appetite suppressant medication that acts by increasing central norepinephrine release.

Option D: Ezetimibe selectively inhibits intestinal absorption of cholesterol and phytosterols, and is used in the management of hypercholesterolemia. It is not indicated in the treatment of obesity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with complaints of weight loss, malaise, and passing loose, bulky stools for the past 4 months. Stools were initially profuse and watery and later became greasy and foul-smelling, often associated with abdominal pain. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown in the image below. All of the following drugs are used to treat this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing the child having loose greasy stools and pain abdomen along with the image showing cysts of Giardia lamblia is strongly suggestive of Giardiasis. For this condition, Metronidazole/tinidazole/Nitazoxanide are the first-line agents while Albendazole is not used in treatment. 

Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water, food, or by the fecal-oral route (hands or fomites). The incubation period is usually about 2 weeks. Cysts are the infective form of the parasite. Cysts are resistant forms and are responsible for the transmission of giardiasis. Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the faeces (diagnostic stages). The cysts are hard and can survive up to 3 months in cold water.

In the small intestine, excystation releases trophozoites (each cyst produces two trophozoites). It is the only common pathogenic protozoan in the human intestines, adhering to the duodenal or upper jejunal mucosa by a ventral sucking disk.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea, fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, belching, and flatulence. The stool contains excess mucus and fat but no blood.
  • Abnormal stool patterns may alternate with periods of constipation and normal bowel movements.
  • It is associated with iron deficiency and growth stunting

Diagnosis:-

  • Wet mount preparation of stool samples for microscopy to identify cysts and trophozoites during the active stage of the disease.
  • The String test/Entero test is used. It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis.
  • Sero diagnosis: Commercially available ELISA kits detect Giardia-specific antigen ( GSA 65 ). ELISA kits (ProSpecT/ Giardia kit) detect Giardia-specific antigen 65 (GSA 65) and have a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 100%, compared to conventional microscopy.

Treatment: Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents.

Other options :

Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery which can be acute intestinal amebiasis presenting with dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence, or chronic amebiasis which presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhoea, weight loss, and fatigue. Fat malabsorption is not commonly seen.

Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoa and it is present in the large intestine as a commensal. It is also the largest protozoan parasite of humans. Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish on wet mount which can be easily differentiated from Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes with a history of chronic weight loss, loss of appetite, and diarrhea along with pale bulky stools and is diagnosed with malabsorption syndrome. Steatorrhea is defined in this patient by stool fat exceeding:
questions.solution:
Steatorrhea is a symptom defined by stool fat exceeding 7 g per day.

Steatorrhea is the passage of greasy, foul-smelling, difficult-to-flush stools. It is often associated with weight loss & nutritional deficiencies due to concomitant malabsorption of amino acids & fat-soluble vitamins. It is one of the clinical features of fat malabsorption and is noted in many conditions causing intraluminal maldigestion, mucosal malabsorption, or lymphatic obstruction.

Causes of steatorrhea:

  • Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency: Chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis (CF), pancreatic tumors
  • Bile acid deficiency: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), ileal resection, Crohn disease, small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
  • Enteropathy or Malabsorption syndrome: Celiac disease (most common), tropical sprue, giardiasis, Whipple disease, amyloidosis, SIBO, abetalipoproteinemia

Screening of steatorrhea is by the detection of fat by Sudan III staining. Stool fat can be quantified by calculating the coefficient of fat absorption (CFA), which is an essential step in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. He recently also developed severe pain in his right knee. A malabsorption syndrome is suspected and a biopsy is taken which shows the following picture. A disturbance in which phase of nutrient absorption is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing foul-smelling diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and histopathology showing dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria and macrophages containing periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules is suggestive of Whipple disease where there is a disturbance in the lymphatic transport of absorbed lipids.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and central nervous system & cardiac problems. The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive fecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-colored stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn's disease. In Whipple disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

  • Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.
  • Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman is suffering from diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for the past 3 months. An intestinal biopsy is provided below showing partial villous atrophy and marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Her symptoms do not improve after eliminating gluten from the diet. Which treatment should be administered?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a woman presenting with diarrhoea, floating stools and weight loss for 3 months with given histopathology indicating inflammation of lamina propria and no improvement with a gluten-free diet is suggestive of tropical sprue. The treatment of tropical sprue is tetracycline + folic acid. Because of marked folate deficiency, folic acid is most often given together with broad-spectrum antibiotics for up to 6 months. 

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious aetiology. Patients present with diarrhoea, steatorrhoea, weight loss, folic acid, and vitamin B12 deficiency.

The small intestinal mucosal biopsy is diagnostic and reveals partial villous atrophy and mononuclear cell infiltration in the lamina propria.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has had a history of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain since 3 years of age. She has pallor, and her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to make a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A small intestinal biopsy can help diagnose documented steatorrhea or chronic diarrhea (>3 weeks). Failure to thrive in the setting of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain suggests a diagnosis of chronic malabsorption.

Endoscopy is the preferred method of obtaining histologic material from the proximal small-intestinal mucosa.

The other options are not specific tests used to confirm malabsorption syndromes.

questions.text: Which of the following tests helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease from irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Assessment of fecal calprotectin levels helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. Hence, they are often assessed to distinguish the two conditions. These tests are also done to check if the disease is active and to detect postoperative recurrence. Other features of IBD include elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), hypoalbuminemia, anemia, and leukocytosis.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of structural abnormalities. There are no clear diagnostic markers for IBS. The presence of anemia, elevated ESR, leukocytosis, bloody stool, or stool volume of more than 200 - 300 ml/day argues against the diagnosis of IBS. The diagnosis is mainly based on clinical presentation.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhoea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this given condition?

choices.text: MARSH score is used for diagnosis of this condition
Histopathological study reveals raised intraepithelial macrophages
Anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with this condition

questions.solution:
The given scenario of diarrhoea and poor appetite and histopathology findings (explained below) are suggestive of celiac disease. Histopathological study reveals raised intraepithelial lymphocytes. Hence, Option C is a false statement.

Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum.  triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals.

Diagnosis:

  • The single best screening test for Celiac disease is Tissue Transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) which has a sensitivity of about 98% & specificity of about 95%.
  • Anti-gliadin antibodies are produced in response to gliadin, a component found in wheat. Antigliadin antibody tests (AGA-IgA and AGA-IgG) have lower diagnostic accuracy. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG) and Anti-endomysial antibodies (Option D) are other antibodies associated with celiac disease.
  • HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 are present in most patients with celiac disease. HLA testing has a positive predictive value of 12 percent. Hence, HLA testing is useful only in ruling out celiac disease. 
  • Endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is used as a confirmatory test to diagnose celiac disease and not as an initial test in suspected cases.
  • The histopathology is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial CD8+T lymphocytes. An increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes is a sensitive marker of celiac disease, even in the absence of epithelial damage and villous atrophy. MARSH's Score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. (Option A)

Dermatitis herpetiformis can occur in as many as 10% of patients. (Option B)

The mainstay of treatment is a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease who underwent multiple sequential ileal resections and removal of his terminal ileum and proximal cecum presents with bloating, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. The lactulose breath test shows a higher-than-normal reading after 1 hour.  Which of the following is the cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Resection of the ileo cecal valve

questions.solution:
Multiple sequential ileal resections, typical of patients with Crohn’s disease can cause short bowel syndrome (<150 cm of the residual small bowel). Flatulence, diarrhea, and a higher than normal concentration of Hydrogen on lactulose breath test make small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) the most likely diagnosis. Resection of the ileocecal valve is the probable cause of his symptoms as it removes the barrier between the small and large bowel allowing for the colonic bacteria to colonise the small intestine. 

Massive intestinal resection (<150 cm of the residual small bowel) results in metabolic and nutritional consequences, is known as short bowel syndrome.

Complications of short bowel syndrome include:

  • Diarrhea (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion, SIBO or unabsorbed bile salts in the colon)
  • Steatorrhea (due to the depletion of the bile salt pool)
  • Gallstones (due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts)
  • Renal stones (due to increased absorption of oxalate in the colon).

SIBO is a condition characterized by overgrowth of bacteria in the small bowel. this can lead to bloating, flatulence, and secretory diarrhea.

Risk factors for SIBO:

  • Surgically created blind loops
  • Short bowel syndrome
  • Decreased intestinal motility
  • Resection of ileocecal valve
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Decreased gastric acid secretion

Diagnosis is by small bowel cultures or Lactulose hydrogen breath test which shows more than 20ppm of hydrogen. Treatment is with an antibiotic like rifaximin. 

Other Options: 

Option A: Bile irritation to the intestinal walls presents with secretory diarrhoea that occurs even at night. However, the presence of a positive lactulose hydrogen breath test makes SIBO more likely in this case.

Option C: Dumping syndrome occurs in patients post Roux en Y jejunal bypass due to direct bypass to the jejunum which leads to symptoms of bloating and abdominal pain. However a positive lactulose hydrogen breath test makes SIBO more likely in this case.

Option D: Increased colonic motility is protective and decreases the incidence of SIBO.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with nausea, watery diarrhea and bloating following the consumption of skimmed milk. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with crampy abdominal pain, bloating and water diarrhea following the consumption of skimmed milk is most likely lactose intolerant with a brush border enzyme deficiency (ie. Lactase). 

Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose. In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms, depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested.

Lactose intolerance is a common cause of adult-onset diarrhea caused by malabsorption that affects individuals aged 20 to 40.  It has been described throughout the world, with significant variations amongst groups.

Lactose is converted to glucose and galactose by intestinal lactase on the brush border of the duodenum. As the osmotic burden of undigested lactose moves through the intestines, it draws water into the lumen and shortens transit time.  Colonic bacteria also ferment lactose, producing short-chain fatty acids and hydrogen gas (bloating).

Foods that are high in lactose include milk (12 g/cup), ice cream (9 g/cup), and cottage cheese (8 g/cup). Aged cheese has lower lactose content. Most people can tolerate up to 12g of lactose a day without significant symptoms.

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance. It contains lactobacillus that produces lactase and is generally well tolerated.

For patients with inconclusive diagnosis, a lactose breath hydrogen test can be performed.

The goal of treatment in patients with isolated lactase deficiency is achieving patient comfort through the elimination of dietary lactose or supplementation with lactase.

Other options :

Option A : Patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency have defective digestion of fat and protein with symptoms of steatorrhea. Patients with pancreatic insufficiency have risk factors such as cystic fibrosis, chronic pancreatitis or a history of bowel or pancreatic resection.

Option D : Luminal bacterial overgrowth is seen in small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) which occurs when colonic bacteria migrate into the small intestine. Diarrhea in SIBO is most likely oily/greasy. It is usually associated with patients with fistulas or a motility disorder. This patient did not present with symptoms of greasy stool nor did he have any underlying disorder making this diagnosis unlikely. 

Option C : Immune mediated damage to the enterocytes are seen in autoimmune conditions such as Celiac disease which leads to damage to the enterocytes as well as villous atrophy. Patients with this disease usually have foul smelling stools or greasy stools which is not seen in this patient making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Intestinal lymphangiectasia?

choices.text: Can occur secondarily due to lymphoma

questions.solution:
Intestinal lymphangiectasia is not primarily a disorder of mucosal absorption, as the issue lies in the lymphatics (post-mucosal absorption) rather than the intestinal mucosa. Hence, Option C is a false statement.

Intestinal lymphangiectasia involves the dilation of intestinal lymphatic vessels, leading to protein loss and fat malabsorption due to impaired lymphatic drainage.

The condition can be either primary (congenital) or secondary. Primary intestinal lymphangiectasia is usually congenital and may be associated with other lymphatic disorders. Secondary causes include conditions that obstruct the lymphatic system, such as lymphoma(Option D), filariasis or constrictive pericarditis. 

The primary issue in intestinal lymphangiectasia is the dilation and dysfunction of the intestinal lymphatic vessels. This leads to the leakage of protein-rich lymph into the gastrointestinal tract, causing protein-losing enteropathy (option A). There is impaired absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins due to the loss of chylomicrons (Option B), which are essential for fat transport.

Patients typically present with:

  • Chronic Diarrhea: Often steatorrhea (fatty stools) due to fat malabsorption.
  • Edema: Resulting from protein loss and hypoalbuminemia.
  • Weight Loss: Due to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • Lymphopenia: Low lymphocyte levels due to the loss of lymphocytes in the gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnosis is usually confirmed by endoscopy and biopsy, showing dilated lymphatic vessels in the mucosa. Laboratory tests typically reveal hypoalbuminemia, hypoproteinemia, and lymphopenia.

Management focuses on:

  • Dietary Modification: A low-fat, high-protein diet supplemented with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) to reduce lymphatic pressure.
  • Medical Therapy: Octreotide, a somatostatin analogue, can be used to reduce lymphatic leakage and manage symptoms.
  • Surgical Intervention: In cases where lymphatic obstruction is localized, surgery may be required to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding IPEX syndrome?

choices.text: It is an X-linked dominant disorder

questions.solution:
IPEX syndrome (Immune dysregulation, Polyendocrinopathy, Enteropathy, X-linked) is an X-linked recessive disorder (not X-linked dominant), primarily affecting males (Option A).

It is caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene. The syndrome manifests early in life with symptoms like Type 1 diabetes, Eczema, and autoimmune enteropathy. It often leads to severe immune system dysregulation.

It is also a primary genetic disorder associated with autoimmune conditions like inflammatory bowel disease(Option D).
